etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French perdiciun, from ecclesiastical Latin perditio(n-), from Latin perdere ‘destroy’, from per- ‘completely, to destruction’ + the base of dare ‘put’

definitions: (in Christian theology) a state of eternal punishment and damnation into which a sinful and unrepentant person passes after death.
shortDefinitions: state of eternal punishment and damnation into which sinful and unrepentant person passes after death

examples.text: she used her last banknote to buy herself a square meal before perdition
